importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the arrest and the incident at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, highlighting a timely intervention that prevented a potential mass shooting.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time Cagle arrived at the airport and began approaching the TSA security checkpoint, indicating the precise moment when the threat was identified and acted upon.

keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle, a 49-year-old convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after a family alerted authorities to his social media livestream threat to 'shoot it up' at the airport.
Cagle was found in possession of an AR-15 assault rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in his Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the terminal.
The incident was prevented due to early warning from family members who reported his social media posts, which described intent to inflict harm on a large scale.
Cagle was charged with making terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, possession of a firearm during the commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a felon.
Authorities confirmed he was not legally allowed to possess the firearm, and federal investigation is underway to determine how he obtained it.
A key community figure, Nick Roberts, reported concerns about Cagle's mental health, noting he had previously stated he was schizophrenic and on medication, though he assured friends he was fine.
The arrest was described by police and officials as a success due to timely intervention and community vigilance.
The mayor of Atlanta and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem both expressed gratitude for the averted tragedy and praised the role of public awareness and information-sharing.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Billy Joe Cagle, a 49-year-old convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after family members alerted police to a social media livestream in which he declared his intent to 'shoot it up' at the airport. Authorities found an AR-15 assault rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in his Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the terminal. Cagle had been seen approaching the TSA security checkpoint and was taken into custody after police, using a photo provided by his family, approached him and detained him. He was charged with multiple offenses, including terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, and unlawful firearm possession. The incident was averted due to early warning from family members, highlighting the importance of public vigilance and community reporting. Officials, including police chief Darin Schierbaum, mayor Andre Dickens, and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem, praised the successful outcome and the role of timely information in preventing a tragedy.
title: Man Arrested at Atlanta Airport After Social Media Threat to Shoot Up Terminal
